All technology tears apart what came before as it builds something new. Technology is now transforming, in many negative ways, the ownership of intellectual property. Not all change is progress.

3D printers will transform manufacturing and will again challenge long established laws and social conventions regarding controlling of patents (intellectual property again) and access to the making of things. It will lead to many innovations in new materials and will lead us to a brave new world where commodities from the earth are less important, or perhaps different ones will be important, as materials become more lab created. Hold on, this is going to be a bumpy ride.

Two points
1) Regardless of the utility of the stuff or services being produced, it still matters how the resulting measure of production (meaning dollars) are distributed. And if the actual value added to society each year (productivity increase of 1% even in slow years) is illusionary, which I would agree with, it doesn't negate the necessity of fighting for a fair share of the increase.
2) Krugman previously stated only 5% of the 15% decrease in manufacturing (meaning drops from 30% share of GDP to 15%) can be attributed to global imports while ignoring the larger implication of globalization. Exporting manufacturing also creates incentives to decrease all manufacturing. There is also a dialectic or spiral, people lack jobs and money to buy stuff so less stuff is made. Companies learn less manufacturing is better. Make money in finance, no headaches from unions, suppliers, inventory management. The only good worker is a low paid worker. What if all iphones were made entirely in the U.S, and cost $1,000 instead of $600 and the workers were paid $50/hour and everyone's income for the bottom 80% were paid $1/hour more than they are now? That's $2,000/year more so same number of iphones are sold, plus another $1,600 of manufactured goods. All of a sudden manufacturing makes up a larger share of the economy, yet everyone prospers (except the 1%) even thought stuff costs more. Take that into your gedanken.

The new technologies, by in large, destroy pricing power of almost everything under the theory the market will be expanded. Same underlying production capacity or less but prices go down.  The only prices that are going up are of scarce assets, art, cable tv monopolies, real estate in markets constrained by legal or physical limitations to expansion. It is what it is but its certainly not better since the "creative destruction"  outliers are   just destructors.  Most of the "successful" businesses like Amazon and Netflix have simply destroyed the existing retail infrastructure and huge number of jobs with it and Google is on is way to destroying the ad based industries which support filmed entertainment.

I was really surprised about the comment that incomes were sluggish in the 70s. I remember reading that the 70s had the highest rate of real (adjusted for inflation) wage growth of any decade on record. And this agrees with my experience and that of my friends who were in their 20s during the 70s. Jobs were plentiful and even though inflation was high, pay raises were much higher.

I've seen a lot of talk about the 70s being bad, but I always thought that's because it was bad for investors and therefore wealthy people and corporations. But of course Paul Krugman isn't one of these people. Really surprised he said this. I generally really like his articles and agree with most of what he has to say.

I must confess that I am a bit conflicted here as I am in the non-enviable position of being a Paul Krugman fan and a tech-creator, one of the developer/engineers actually inventing those "watch" type of things for Fortune 500.

Technology's job is to automate mundane tasks and make production of goods and services cheaper, on that it excels remarkably but it can not re-create a social system where actual needs of the society can be met by about 20-30 percent of our population.

Yes, some may think this number is too low but with all the automation in place and if we take away advertisement driven over consumption out of the equation, our modern society's needs can be met with about one in three adults being full time employed.

The real problem/issue here is our society is not equipped to deal with extra-ordinary efficiency arising from technology... all rents of this new "factor" is accumulating with capital owners and with people like me (to a small extent).

Out-sized opportunities for very few while rest of the population's overall economic condition decline.

Only solution I can see is radical transformation of our society from one of consume-produce (we do not need that many workers any more) rat race to something more balanced.

We used to be hunter-gatherers, then became specialist consumer-producers and now we got digitized... it is that simple.

Take effect of marketing out of Economy and real picture of how many people need to "work" will blow your mind.

Yeah, well, one thing is for certain. Everything we develop in the tech world, which should put us on top, is being stolen. Our tech bonanza is like drug companies developing new drugs without patents.

We've let our manufacturing base pretty much rot away, in stark contrast to Germany, and we now lead only in digital technology, which gets stolen the moment we produce it.

So, of course we are losing. We are suckers being bled to death by China, and the position at the top we gained by coming out ahead at the end of World War 2 has been utterly lost.

That is why our middle class is tanking. It's coming down to the level of the rest of the planet, and there are plenty of folks outside our borders who have a much stronger work ethic.

In short, we are spoiled, naive, and increasingly stupid as we let our educational infrastructure collapse along with the rest of our infrastructure. So none of this should be a surprise.

When I was at University in the mid-seventies I attended a public lecture by a writer (name forgotten) who digressed on the threat of jobs as technology used people to increase productivity. An engineering professor in the front objected and engaged the speaker with his opinion: machines should never be allowed to use people; people must always use machines to improve the human condition.

The global economy tends to resemble a complicated shell game. Under some shells are deferred tax revenues booked off-shore; another shell may contain low-paid worker bees in China producing intellectual property (IP) that is owned and controlled under another shell - mostly by America's business and scientific elite.

In the annuals of technology history it may be said that the architecture and language (HTTP) of the Internet was designed by physicist Tim Berners-Lee working at CERN in Switzerland. What is not commonly known is that it took a couple of very smart American professors at Stanford to make the Internet plumbing work to scale capacity. Stanford engineers with colleagues at MIT transformed the Internet protocols to make the Internet responsive to significant data traffic while ensuring that packets sent were received with accuracy.

Productivity is found in Boston and Silicon Valley's Technology-Industrial Complex that generated IP that dominates the world and allowed the evolution of information and communications technologies to leverage all current Internet applications.

its not " technology". its the "networked economy" that kills us. technology as tool helped build america from 1900 -1960- then all of a sudden we allowed the networked affect of technology as media to take over. changing what was small, personal-private and human scale transactions into large impersonal machine scale mechanizations. we choose a non humanscale future since $$ have no humanscale either. we are left holding nothing, because we cant fit what weve made in our hands thus we made the corporation the human, and gave it all rights.

We have collectively been down the path to being amused by virtual reality TV, celebrity worship now extended to the 1% Masters of the Universe and it is difficult to see a change in direction given the sellout by their Congress.

For sure the problems started around the 1930s. The economy is largely built up from the mental habits of all of the people, which dictate the extent to which they will work hard and allocate their time wisely, their "mental motivational complex" if you will, or simply "conscience". But instead of realizing this crucial fact, a small number of people used the technology of mass communication to exploit the average person, encourage bad habits, and reflect the most venal, selfish, and cruel aspects of the human experience by exploiting human weakness. The result has been a disaster. Media that would serve to educate and enlighten was systematically eliminated because it wasn't "popular". The people have been led to a swamp, a cesspool, by the ones entrusted with reflecting their highest aspirations. Had Edward Bernays and the founders of public relations been decent people, had they used their power for good instead of evil, we could have had a self-supporting society instead of a society designed to dehumanize and exploit. So now we live in a cancerous, toxic world instead of a decent, humane world. A tiny number of people are responsible for this situation. Blame them, for they are the ones who were entrusted with the future, and they have failed. Power corrupts, and the power to guide the mental habits of the masses has been allocated in a way that has corrupted the leaders and given the average person the idea that narcissism is normal. We need to clean house.

I'd love to have a fuller accounting of knowledge and music, as I think the arts get at some of the thornier aspects of knowledge. Musicians have wildly different conceptions of what it means to know a piece of music (to be able to play it, to understand it theoretically, to have a sense of its history and culture, etc.). Even knowing a scale, or knowing the notes of a piece, can have wildly different meanings.
Ah, but now they are saying there's more arsenic in brown rice, so we should switch back to white.

There are cultural factors to consider as well. I grew up eating a lot of white rice. In some cultures, kids who are "chubby" are seen as well fed and taken care of and the food they normally eat is high in fat. Skinny kids are perceived as being under fed. All kids and teens need to be fed balanced healthy meals and snacks. A doctor I recently met said to watch portions and strive for half of the dinner plate filled with fruits and vegetables and ease off the white bread and white rice and choose whole grains and brown rice. Portions are out of control at restaurants and kids' meals (chicken nuggets/fries, pizza, butter noodles, mac/cheese) at restaurants are pathetic at best. School lunches are dismal and need an overhaul, even the ones packed at home. After-school snacks need to be healthy and convenient. Some public schools in my area have a healthy-eating curriculum sponsored by a local hospital that has dietitians train parents to give mini-lessons in class about healthy food choices. A food tasting is included in the lesson.

Seems to me rather telling that a "liberal" like Krugman doesn't see the divide between the really rather stodgy economic paradigms whose interests he serves and the reality that advances in technology strain that paradigm. In other words, just because his paradigm is going "meh" doesn't mean that tech is "meh"; just that the old way--where markets churn way, overproducing and endlessly metastasizing--isn't well-served by what technology seems to be progressively dishing up. I think it's all coming to roost in a realization that the old guard Wobbly contingent may be on to something: Real technical advancements open the door for the old socialist normalization of production.

I found the 2012 Hanzell "Sebella", and the 2013 Failla and Lioco, so only the Lioco was the recommended vintage.  After the diversity of muscadel last month, I concur with Ali that these chardonnays were all of a piece, not identical, but quite similar.  I also wish to associate myself with Ferguson's and Ali's opinions that these wines could be felt in the front of the mouth.  That's a better description than any I could come up with.  The Hanzell had an intense initial sensation that quickly vanished, while the others were less extreme.  My fave was the Failla, which for me had the best balance.
